question: Are you dictating my position to me? We're getting into some sticky legal territories here.
answer: Martha, all we're saying is, no-one wants this to come to trial, not the Church, not the Crown... least of all me.

question: Eve, she strangled a baby!
answer: Nobody is interested in sending a nun to prison.

question: Bonjour, I'm Doctor Martha Livingston, I... Well... I...
answer: I'm afraid the word brings up the most unpleasant connatations in this day and age...

question: ... Thank you.
answer: You must have tons of questions. You may smoke if you want to. Just don't tell any of the Sisters.

question: How did she hide it from the other nuns?
answer: She undressed alone... she bathed alone.

question: How did she hide it during the day?
answer: She could have hidden a machine gun in here if she had wanted to.

question: Didn't she have any physical examinations
answer: We're examined once a year. Her pregnancy fell in between the doctor's visits.

question: What man had access to her?
answer: None as far as I know.

question: What's his name?
answer: Father Martineau, but I don't see him as a candidate.

question: Could there have been anyone else?
And you didn't try to find out who?
answer: Believe me, I've done everything possible short of asking Agnes.

question: Why haven't you asked her?
answer: She can't even remember the birth. Do you think she'd admit to the conception?

question: Look, someone gave her the baby.
answer: Yes, but that was some ten months ago. I fail to see that the identity of that somebody has anything to do with this trial.

question: Why do you think that?
answer: Don't ask me those questions dear, I'm not the patient.

question: Well I'm the doctor. I'm the one who's going to decide what is, or is not important here.
answer: Look doctor, I don't know how to tell you this politely, but I don't approve of you. Not you personally...

question: The science of psychiatry.
answer: Exactly. I want you do deal with Agnes as speedily and as easily as possible. She won't hold up under any sort of cross examination.

question: I am not with the Inquisition.
answer: And I am not from the Middle Ages. I know what you are! I don't want that mind cut open.

question: Hello. I'm Doctor Livingston. I've been asked to talk to you. May I?
Hasn't anyone ever told you that before?
What would you like to talk about.
First thing that comes to your mind?
answer: God! But there's nothing to say about God.

question: Second thing that comes to your mind.
Agnes, have you ever loved another man... other than, Jesus Christ?
Well do you love... do you love Father Martineau?
Do you think he loves you?
He's told you?
answer: No. But... when I look into his eyes, I can tell.

question: Agnes, do ever see Father Martineau outside the...
answer: You want to talk about the baby don't you?

question: Would you like to talk about it?
answer: I never saw any baby... I think they made it up.

question: Do you remember the night they said it came?
In the middle of all the pain?
Where did the baby come from?
Is that where they say it came from... ?
answer: No, they say it came from the waste paper basket!

question: Where'd it come from before that?
After God... before the waste-paper basket.
Yes I do, but I want you to...
answer: I don't understand what you're talking about... you want to talk about the baby... everybody wants

question: Then let's talk about something else...
answer: No... no, I'm tired of talking, I've been talking for weeks, nobody believes me when I tell them anything... nobody listens to me.

question: Agnes...
answer: No... no, I don't want to answer any more questions.

question: Would you like to ask them?
Just that... you ask and I'll answer.
I can't have them any more.
Smoking is an obsession with me. Maybe one day I'll become obsessed with something else, then I'll stop smoking... Do you have any more questions?
What?
answer: Where do you think babies come from?

question: From their mothers and fathers of course. Before that, I... I don't know.
answer: Well I think they come from... angel lights on their mothers chest and whispers into her ear. That makes good babies start to grow. And bad babies come from when a fallen angel squeezes in down there, and they start to grow, grow, till they come out down there. I don't know where good babies come out. And you can't tell the difference... except bad babies cry a lot... and they make their fathers go away... and their mothers get very ill... die sometimes.

question: Well... what do you think? Is she totally bananas or merely slightly off centre... or maybe she's perfectly sane and just a very good liar.
I believe Agnes is different.
answer: From other nuns... Yes I... I've noticed.

question: From other people! I believe she is not crazy, nor is she lying.
answer: How could she have a baby and know nothing of sex or birth?

question: Because she's an innocent. She's a slate that's hasn't been touched except by God. In her case it isn't. She's had very little schooling. Her mother kept her home almost all the time and when her mother died Agnes came here, to us. She's never been out there Doctor. She's never seen a movie or a television show. She's never even read a book.
answer: If she's so innocent, how come she murdered a child?

question: She didn't! This is manslaughter, not murder. She didn't consciously kill that baby. She'd lost a lot of blood. She was unconscious by the time we got to her.
answer: So, someone else could have done it.

question: No... not in the eyes of the police.
I've already told you what I thought.
answer: That she was unconscious, yes! So someone easily could have come in the room and killed the...

question: You don't really believe something like that happened do you?
Who?
answer: One of the other nuns found out about the baby and... and wanted to avoid a scandal.

question: That's absurd!
answer: That possibility never occurred to you?

question: No-one knew about Agnes' pregnancy. No-one. Not even Agnes.
answer: Is Father Martineau in please? ??? And you're the only man to see them? Hello, Mama ... brought you something.

question: Is Father Martineau in please? ??? And you're the only man to see them? Hello, Mama ... brought you something.
answer: Shut up, I'm trying to watch this.

question: It's Martha, Mama. There you go.
answer: Marie brings me icecream too you know. Chocolate... my favourite.

question: I thought cherry-vanilla was your favourite.
answer: Not any more... now I like chocolate.

question: Did you have a good week Mama. Are they treating you all right?
answer: You know Martha never comes to see me. You watch it, she's going straight to hell... after all the things she said to me. Then she marries that son of a bitch of a Frenchman... has an abortion. I knew that one wouldn't work out. Not like you Marie. You got married to God.

question: Marie's dead Mama.
answer: I remember when you was a little girl Marie. You come back from the movies and you'd say - Mama that ending was so sad... and I'd tell you they had all the happy endings locked away in a vault in Hollywood. And you believed me.

question: Mama, that wasn't Marie, that was me!
I... I'm Martha, Mama.
answer: The convent was built for over fifty. Not many of us left... just us and the chickens.

question: How do you survive?
answer: Oh, we own the land around here. But we rent it out. We keep a few acres for ourselves, some wheat, corn, some vegetables.

question: Well that's a lot of land. You must have help. Do you have field hands that help you?
answer: No. We work the land alone. No-one but Sister Marguerite and I are permitted contact with the public.

question: Sister Anne, which was Agnes' room?
answer: Oh that one there, in the corner.

question: The one up on the third floor?
Uh huh.
answer: This convent is locked solid. The only one that has a key is Sister Marguerite and she wouldn't let Christ in after dark.

question: Well, it's been known to happen in the day too. Maybe Agnes went to him.
answer: Oh come on, you've talked to her. She doesn't even know how babies are born, let alone made.

question: When did you first learn about her... innocence, the way she thinks?
answer: Shortly after she came to us.

question: And you weren't shocked?
answer: I was appalled, just as you are now.

question: This was before her pregnancy?
answer: About two years before. Agnes, it has come to my attention that you have stopped eating. Why is this?

question: About two years before. Agnes, it has come to my attention that you have stopped eating. Why is this?
Oh, for Heaven's sake.
answer: I am, there's too much flesh on me.

question: Why does it matter whether you're fat or not...
... You needn't worry about being attractive here.
answer: I do, I have to be attractive to God.

question: He loves you the way you are.
answer: No he doesn't. He hates fat people.

question: Who told you this?
answer: It's a sin to be fat.

question: Why?
answer: Look at the statues, they're thin.

question: Agnes...
answer: That's because they're suffering... suffering is beautiful, I want to be beautiful.

question: Who tells you these things?
answer: Christ said it in the Bible, he said - suffer the little children, I want to suffer like a little child.

question: That's not what he meant.
answer: I... I am a little child but my body keeps getting bigger and soon I... I won't be able to fit in, I... I won't be able to squeeze into Heaven.

question: Agnes dear, Heaven is not a place where...
answer: No... I mean... I mean look at these. I've got to lose weight, I'm a blimp.

question: Oh my dear child.
answer: God blew up the Hindenburg. He'll blow me up, that's what she said...

question: Who?
answer: Mommy I'll get bigger and bigger every day and then I'll pop but... but if I stay little it won't happen.

question: Your mother tells you this?... Agnes your mother is dead.
Nonsense, I'm your mother now and I want you to eat.
You've got to eat something Agnes.
answer: No I don't... the host is enough.

question: My dear, I don't think a communion wafer has the recommended daily allowance of anything.
Dear Jesus...
answer: It started this morning and I can't get it to stop.

question: Why didn't you take her to a doctor?
answer: It was healed by the following morning and she started eating again...

question: She had a... a hole in the palm of her hand! She could have bled to death.
answer: But she didn't... did she. If anyone had seen what I'd seen she'd be public property... newspapermen, psychiatrists, ridicule. She doesn't deserve that.

question: She has it now.
answer: I know what you're thinking, she's a hysteric pure and simple.

question: Not simple, no.
answer: I saw it. Clean through the palm of her hand. Do you think hysteria could do that?

question: It's being doing it for centuries. She's not unique, she's just another victim.
answer: God's victim. That's her innocence. She belongs to God.

question: And I intend to take her away from Him. That's what you're afraid of isn't it?
Look there are a lot of unanswered questions here. I know my job. Don't tell me my job Lyon. My duty as a doctor is to...
answer: Martha, you have to make a decision on her sanity as quickly as possible and not interfere with due process of law.

question: No... no, excuse me Eve. As quickly as I see fit.
answer: The longer you take to make a decision, the more difficult it will be for us.

question: Why?
answer: The bishop is breathing down our necks.

question: I don't believe this. I don't bloody believe this. I'm fighting for this woman's life, not some bloody bishop. You liked Sister Paul?
answer: She was kind to me. She told me I was beautiful.

question: What else did she tell you?
answer: She said all of God's angels would want to sleep beside me if they could. I liked that.

question: Where's that?... I promise I won't tell, would you take me? Sister Paul was in her eighties? Did she climb up here often?
answer: No, only when she felt like it. She brought me up here last winter and the next day she died.

question: No wonder... wait... Agnes... Agnes how do you feel about babies?
answer: Oh, they frighten me, I'm afraid I'll drop them. They have a soft spot on their heads and if you drop them so they land on their heads they become stupid. I was dropped on my head, that's why I don't understand things.

question: Like what?
answer: Numbers... you can spend your whole life counting and never reach the end.

question: I don't understand them either. Do you suppose I was dropped on my head?
answer: I hope not. It's a terrible thing to be dropped on your head.

question: Oh, I've got to give up smoking. Agnes ... wait a minute... Agnes slow down.
answer: She said you could see the whole world from up here. But it looks much better far away than it looks close up.

question: Beautiful...
answer: And sometimes I get under here... it makes a wonderful sound.

question: What happens if the bell rings and you're under there?
answer: Oh, it's even more wonderful then.

question: It's like hiding from my mother when I was a little girl.
Oh, no place as wonderful as this. Agnes... have you ever thought of leaving the convent for something else?
answer: No. There is nothing else. Just being here at night helps me sleep.

question: You have trouble sleeping?
answer: I get headaches. Mommy did too... oh, but she wasn't stupid. She knew things that nobody else knew.

question: What things?
answer: She knew what was going to happen to me. That's why she hid me away.

question: I promise I won't laugh. Who told her?
answer: An angel, when she was having one of her headaches.

question: Did your mother see angels often?
Do you believe she really saw them?
answer: No, but I can never tell her that.

question: Agnes, did you love your mother?
Did you ever want to be a mother yourself?
answer: I could never be a mother.

question: Why not?
answer: Well I don't think I'm old enough and besides I don't want to have a baby.

question: If you did want one, how'd you go about getting one?
answer: From someone who didn't want to have a baby.

question: How would that person get one if they didn't want one?
Agnes, how did your mother get you?
answer: A mistake... it was a mistake...

question: Is that what she said?
answer: If you're trying to get me to say that she was a bad woman and hated me and didn't want me but that's not true, she was a good woman, a saint...

question: Agnes, I don't believe you know nothing about sex...
answer: I can't help it if I'm stupid.

question: ... that you don't remember getting pregnant...
... and that you don't believe you carried a child.
Agnes...
answer: Don't touch me like that! You don't touch me like that, I know what you want from me, you want to take God away. You should be ashamed, they should lock you up people like you.

question: The Catholic Church...
answer: I haven't said anything against the the Catholic Church.

question: Catholicism is not on trial here. I want you to deal with Agnes without any religious prejudice or you turn this case over to someone else...
answer: How dare you tell me to run my affairs!

question: It's my affair too.
answer: How dare you think I'm in a position to be pressured...

question: I'm only interested...
answer: ... or bullied or what ever you're doing. Who the hell do you think you are? You go around here expecting applause for the way you treated this child.

question: She is not a child.
answer: And she has a right to know that there's a world out there filled with people who don't believe in God...
??? ... virginity, right Mother? Poverty, chastity and ignorance is what you live by.

question: I am not a virgin, Doctor. I was married for twenty three years, two daughters. I even have grandchildren... surprised? It might please you to know that I was a failure as a wife and mother. My children won't even see me any more, that's their revenge. I think they tell their friends that I've passed on. And don't tell me I'm making up for past mistakes Doctor Freud.
I am...
answer: No, you're shielding her. Let her face the world.

question: What good would it do. No matter what you decide it's either the... the prison or the nut house and the differences between them are pretty thin.
How?
answer: Innocence. Legal innocence. I know the judge would be happy for any reason to throw this case out of court.

question: All right, what do you need.
answer: Answers. When would Agnes have conceived the child?

question: Oh, some time in January.
answer: Do you remember anything unusual happening at the time?

question: Nothing.
answer: Do you have a... a diary or a day book?

question: Oh, Dear God, I should have guessed... ... I should have suspected something. Sister Marguerite says you have been sleeping on a bare mattress Sister. Is that true?
Why?
answer: In the medieval days the nuns and monks would sleep in their own coffins.

question: We're not in the Middle Ages, Sister.
It made them uncomfortable. And if
Then tell me. Where are your sheets?
How many times have I burned into your thick skull and the thick skull of your fellow novice, that menstruation is a perfectly natural process and nothing to be ashamed of.

Say it! Mean it! A few years ago one of the Sisters came to me in tears, asking for comfort, comfort because she was too old to have any children. Not that she wanted to, but once a month she had been reminded of that possibility.
answer: It's not that... it's not that...

question: What do you mean?
answer: It's not my time of month.

question: Should you see a doctor?
answer: I don't know. I don't know what happened Mother, I woke up... there was blood on the sheets, but I don't know what happened. I don't know what I did wrong, I don't know and I should be punished.

question: For what?
answer: I don't know... I don't know...

question: That was the beginning, the night of the conception. That's why she burnt the sheets.
The twenty third of January. On that night one of our elder nuns passed away.
Yes. I don't remember where Agnes was. I was needed in the sick room.
No.
answer: Well you're probably right about that. It certainly can't help Sister Agnes to have this investigation continued for any length of time.

question: Why do you call it an investigation? I never have.
answer: Your mother was a resident of Saint Catherines home before you moved her.

question: What does this have to do with..?
answer: And you had a sister who died in the convent.

question: Who told you this?
answer: Do you still go to church?

question: What business is it of yours..?
answer: Oh, we just wonder if you can be very objective about this case.

question: Look, Father, ah... just because I don't subscribe to the... to the beliefs you subscribe to...
answer: But what you believe makes no difference to us whatsoever Doctor. But it does

question: I don't understand. Are you expecting me to..?
answer: Well somone's got to suffer for this Doctor. You've got to be merciful and quick. Excuse me.

question: Agnes, I'm here because I want to help you.
But you're troubled... aren't you?
answer: That's because you keep reminding me. If you go away then I'll forget.

question: Agnes...
answer: Answer me! You never answer me.

question: Sometimes, yes.
answer: Only you think you're lucky because you didn't have a mother who said things to you and did things to you that maybe weren't always nice but that was because of me, because I was bad, not her.

question: Agnes. What did your mother do to you? If you can't answer me, just shake your head yes or no. Did... did she hit you? Did she make you do something you didn't want to? Did it make you feel uncomfortable to do it? Did it embarrass you? Did it... did it hurt you? What did she make you you do?
She can't hurt you any more.
Agnes, I don't believe that. Tell me. I'll protect you from her.
Yes?
answer: ... take off my clothes and then... she makes fun of me.

question: That you're a mistake?
answer: She says my whole body's a mistake.

question: Why?
answer: Because she says if I don't watch out I'll have a baby.

question: What?
answer: She touches me down there with a cigarette. Please Mommy, don't touch me like that any more. I'll be good, I won't be a baby any more.

question: Agnes, oh Agnes, Agnes I want you to do something. I want you to pretend that I'm your mother. Oh yes, only this time I want you to tell me what you're feeling, alright?
Please! I want to help you. Let me help you.
Agnes, you're ugly!... what do you say? Of course you do. Agnes, you're ugly!... what do you say?
You're a mistake.
answer: I'm not mistake, I'm here aren't I. How can I be a mistake if I'm really here. God doesn't make mistakes, you're a mistake...

question: Oh Agnes, oh Agnes, it's alright, it's alright, it's alright, it's alright, I love you.
answer: Do you really love me or are you just saying that?

question: I really love you.
answer: As much as Mother Miriam does?

question: As much as God loves you. Agnes? Who? Mother Superior? What? Sister... Oh, Good afternoon Sister, I... I'm looking for some biographical data on Sister Agnes, and Mother said I might find it here. Thank you. You lied to me
Your niece!
answer: I didn't tell you because I didn't think it was important.

question: No, it just makes you doubly responsible doesn't it?
answer: I never saw Agnes until she set foot in this convent. My sister ran away from home. We lost touch with her. And when my husband died and I came here, she wrote to me and asked me if I would take care of Agnes in case anything happened.

question: And Agnes' father?
answer: It could have been any one of a dozen men from what my sister told me.

question: Like keeping her home from school?
Listening to angels?
answer: She drank too much. That's what killed her.

question: Do you know what she did to her?
answer: I don't think I care to know.

question: There is more here than meets the eye isn't there? Lots of dirty little secrets.
answer: Oh God, if only I'd known.

question: Why didn't you? You knew she was keeping her home from school. You knew she was an alcoholic.
answer: I knew that after the fact.

question: Why didn't you do anything to stop her?
Oh, God. Larry...
answer: Marty, what are you doing here?

question: Larry there's got to be something missing.
answer: I gave you the pictures Marty, what else do you want?

question: Something they... that they overlooked.
answer: What? You think that the girl is innocent?

question: Larry...
answer: What's the matter with you, you've seen the reports. It's a cut and dried case.

question: Maybe there's something that's not in the report that should be.
answer: You're too involved Marty. Jesus look at you. Why don't you turn this case over to someone else?

question: Thanks.
answer: If I find anything I'll call you. Hi Marty, it's me. Listen I just talked with Detective Crawley who was at the convent. She said that there was one thing that bothered her that didn't make it into the report. The waste paper basket. The one in Agnes' room. None of the other nuns had one. Bye. ... her that didn't make it into the report. The waste paper basket. The one in Agnes' room. None of the other nuns had one. Bye.

question: I've gotten the court's permission to hypnotise her.
The woman's health is at stake.
I don't give a damn about her spiritual health.
Sentence her and be done with it, that's what you're saying and I...
answer: I am saying a beautifully simple woman...

question: An unhappy woman...
answer: She's happy with us and she could go on being happy if she was left alone.

question: Then why did you call the police in the first place Mother, huh?
answer: Because I am a moral person.

question: Catholic Church doesn't have a corner on morality...
answer: Who said anything about the Catholic Church...

question: You just said...
answer: What the hell has the Catholic Church got to do with you?

question: Nothing...
answer: What have we done to hurt you? And don't deny it, I can smell an ex-Catholic a mile away. What did we do? Burn a few heretics, sell some indulgences? That was in the days when the Church was a ruling body. We let governments do those things today. So what did we do to you eh? You wanted to neck in the back seat of a car when you were fifteen and you couldn't because it was a sin?

question: It wasn't sex. It was a lot of things, but it wasn't sex. You know when I was in the first grade my best friend was run
That's all? That's enough! She was a beautiful little girl.
answer: And what has that to do with it?

question: I wasn't. I wasn't. She was the pretty one. She died, why not me? I never said my morning prayers. And I was ugly, I was scrawny, I had buck teeth and freckles all over my face, do you know what the nun called me, Sister Mary Clitus, called me Polkadot Livingston.
answer: So you left the Church because you had freckles?

question: No, because I... yeah, yeah I left the Church cause I had freckles.
answer: When I was a child I used to hear my guardian angel. She sang to me 'till I was six years old. That's when I stopped listening. But I remember the voice. A few years ago I looked at myself and saw nothing but a nun who was certain of nothing. Not even of Heaven. Not even of God. And then one evening I saw Agnes standing by

question: My sister died in a convent. And it's her voice I hear. Does my smoking bother you?
Would you like one? Huh?
answer: I'd love one. I'm out of prac... ... practice.

question: Do you suppose the saints would have smoked if tobacco had been popular back then?
answer: Undoubtedly. Not the ascetics of course but, well Saint Thomas More...

question: Long, thin and filtered.
answer: Saint Ignatius would smoke cigars and stub them out on the soles of his bare feet. And of course

question: Oh, you've come a long way baby.
answer: And Saint John would chew tobacco.

question: Right. What do you suppose today's saints are smoking?
answer: There are no saints today. Good people yes, but extraordinarily good people... those I'm afraid we are sorely lacking.

question: Do you think they ever existed?
Do you want to become one?
answer: Become? One is born a saint.

question: Well you can try, can't you, to be good?
answer: Yes, but goodness has very little to do with it. Not all the saints were good, in fact some of them were a little crazy. But... they were still attached to God. Agnes has that birth.

question: Do you think Agnes is still attached to God?
The hypnotism. Do you still disapprove?
answer: Would it stop you if I did?

question: You're listening to a chorus of angels. The music surrounds you like a... warm and, comfortable pool of water. And while you're sleeping, you're going to be able to recall, all the things that we want you to remember. And when I count to three and clap my hands, you'll no longer be hypnotised. Can you hear me.
Good. Would you like to tell me why you're here?
What kind of trouble? What kind of trouble Agnes?
But it's easy. It's just a breath with sound. Say it. What kind of trouble?
How did you have a baby?
Did you know what was going to come
Did you want it to come out?
Why?
answer: May I open my eyes now?

question: No not yet Agnes, very soon but not yet. How did the baby get into you?
What made it grow? Do you know?
Would you like to tell me?
Did anyone else know about the baby?
Will she be angry?
answer: She made me promise not to.

question: Who? Who made you promise? It's alright Agnes. It's alright. Let's go to your room. It's the night about six weeks ago when you were very sick.
Oh don't be, I'm here. It's alright. I want you to tell me what you did before you went to bed.
Hm hmm. What did you have for dinner?
And then what happened?
answer: We went to chapel for vespers.

question: Hm hmm.
answer: I left early because I wasn't feeling very well.

question: Was it Sister Marguerite who knew about the baby? Alright Agnes, I want you to see your room as you saw it on that night.
Above the bed? Any... anything else? What do you you see, something different? What is it?
Do you know who put it there?
What do you think it's there for?
answer: For me to get sick in.

question: What do you feel?
answer: I feel as if I've eaten glass.

question: Of what?
answer: Of me. Oh... God! My God... Water... it's all water...

question: Why isn't anyone coming?
answer: They can't hear me that's why. Oh God... I don't wanna...

question: Who?
answer: Go away, I don't want you here.

question: Is someone in the room with you?
NO... no... I said leave her alone. Alright Agnes... it's alright. One, two three... It's alright... it's me, Doctor Livingston, it's alright, alright. Thankyou Agnes, thankyou. How do you feel?
Do you remember what just happened?
That's good. Do you feel well enough to stand?
There you go. It's alright, it's alright, it's all over. It's alright Agnes, that's right, that's right.
answer: Oh... very interesting I guess... Excuse me...

question: That's how he got in... or she got out.
answer: Oh excuse me, what did you say?

question: Nothing. May I take some notes?
Is the Doctor in her office? General MacArthur.
answer: It's... it's alright Helen, just close the door.

question: I've just met with the bishop. We're taking you off the case.
If we want to hire a psychiatrist for Agnes. we'll find our own, thank you.
answer: One that will ask the questions you want asked.

question: One that will approach this matter with some objectivity and respect.
She's been touched by God, yes.
answer: How? How? She hallucinates, stops eating and bleeds spontaneously. Is that supposed to convince me she shouldn't be touched. Give me a miracle.

question: Why must he be anybody?
answer: My God, you're as crazy as...

question: Stop laughing, I don't say it's the truth, I'm saying...
Don't be ridiculous.
answer: Well give me a reasonable explanation

question: A miracle is an event without an explanation. If she's capable of putting a hole in her hand without benefit of a nail, why couldn't she split a cell in her womb?
There as no man in the convent on that night and no way for any man to get in or out.
No, that's as much as saying Father Martineau did it. I'm saying God permitted it.
You'll never find the answer for everything God did.
answer: I thought you didn't believe in miracles today Mother?

question: But I want the opportunity to believe. I want the choice to believe.
answer: But what you are choosing to believe is a lie because you won't face the fact that she was raped... or seduced... or that she did the seducing.

question: She is an innocent.
answer: But she is not an enigma Mother. Everything that Agnes has done is explainable from modern psychiatry. One, two, three, right down the line.

question: That's what you believe she is? The sum of her psychological parts?
answer: That's what I have to believe...

question: Then why are you so obsessed with her? You're losing sleep over her? You're thinking about her all the time. You're bent on saving her. Why?
answer: There's a tunnel out of the crypt into the barn. Did you know about that? There's an answer Mother. That's how she got out.

question: That's crazy. How could she find out about it?
Who? That tun... that tunnel hasn't been used in fifty years.
answer: Oh, would you stop lying Mother!

question: Why would I lie?
answer: Because it's murder we're talking about. Aren't you concerned about what she told us about the other person in her room.

question: I'm concerned about her health.
answer: Who was that person Mother? Was it you?

question: If you believe this is murder, it is the Crown attorney you have to talk to, not me. And definitely not Agnes.
answer: All I want is one more week.

question: All I want is one more week.
answer: Why? You've done nothing to show any progress.

question: Yes, that's because I'm getting to her.
answer: You're getting to all of us Martha, let's face it.

question: I'll have a decision by next week.
answer: It's gone on long enough. You're out.

question: Oh Joe... Joe she didn't kill the baby.
I can get you new evidence next week.
Tomorrow... tomorrow, I'll get it by tomorrow. I will.
This is permission to take her apart.
Hasn't she had enough?
answer: I have a few more questions to ask her.

question: Why do you insist upon pressing...
Is it because she's a nun?
answer: Did you know she was pregnant?

question: Yes.
answer: And you didn't send her to a doctor.

question: I didn't guess until it was too late.
I don't know... too late to stop it.
The scandal...
answer: You went to the room to help with the birth.

question: She didn't want any help.
answer: You wanted that child out of the way.

question: That's a lie.
answer: You hid the wastepaper basket in her room.

question: I didn't hide it. I put it there for the blood and the dirty sheets.
No!
answer: You tied the cord around its neck.

question: I wanted her to have it when no-one else was around, they would have taken the baby to a hospital and left it with them, but it was such a difficult birth, there was so much blood and I panicked.
answer: Before or after you killed the child?

question: I left it with her and I went for help.
answer: I doubt that's what she'd say.

question: I want you to remember if you can a night last January. The night Sister Paul died. Do you remember.
What did she mean?
answer: The statue. She had shown it to me the day before.

question: And the passage to the barn?
Why?
answer: So I could go to him.

question: How did she know about him?
Where?
answer: From the belltower the day she before she died.

question: Are you frightened?
answer: Yes. Hallo... ... where are you? Is it you?

question: What do you see?
answer: Halos... ... dividing and dividing feathers and starts, falling, falling into the iris of God's eye. Oh... oh!... it's... it's so lovely... it's so... blue... yellow... blood wings, brown, blood... His blood... my God...

question: Oh Agnes...
answer: It's bleeding... I'm bleeding... my God it won't stop, I can't get it to stop. Let go of me, I wish you were dead.

question: Agnes it had nothing to do with the hand of God. He did a terrible thing to you, do you understand?
He frightened you and he hurt you. It's not your fault. It's his fault. Tell us who he is so we can find him. Stop him from doing this to other women.
Of course you do. Who was it?
answer: I hate him for what he did to me.

question: Yes.
answer: For what he made me go through.

question: Agnes, who did this to you?
answer: God! It was God. And now I'll burn in hell because I hate him.

question: Agnes you won't burn in hell. It's alright to hate him.
Agnes, what happened to the baby?
Mother Miriam was with you wasn't she?
She took the baby in her arms?
You saw it all didn't you?
And then... what did she do? Agnes what did she do?
answer: She... left me alone with that little thing, and I looked at it, and I thought this is a mistake. But it's my mistake, not Mommy's. God's mistake.

question: H... how?
answer: I tied the cord around her neck... wrapped her in the bloody sheets... and stuffed her in the trash can.
